references.B98PET01NCGP: Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.
references.W14IUC99USGP: IUCN. 2014. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1. http://www.iucnredlist.org. Downloaded March 2016.
references.B84MOU01SEGP: Mount, R.H, (ed). 1984  Vertebrate Wildlife of Alabama, Alabama Agricultural Experiment Station, Auburn University, 44 pp.
references.B61SMI01NAUS: Smith, P. W. 1961. The amphibians and reptiles of Illinois. Illinois Natural History Survey 28:1-298.
references.B96RED01NAUS: Redmond, W. H., and A. F. Scott. 1996. Atlas of amphibians in Tennessee. The Center for Field Biology, Austin Peay State University, Miscellaneous Publication Number 12. v + 94 pp.
references.B95WIL01NCGP: Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.

habitat_description: Cave salamanders occur in and around caves and in areas with karst topography (Mount 1984).  Adults are often abundant in forested habitats in or near rock walls or ledges with springs at their bases and extensive cracks that allow access to underground passages (Petranka 1998).  Primarily associated with limestone.  They are typically found inhabiting crevices in steep bluffs, rock outcrops, rocky mesic ravines, and the twilight zone of caves (Redmond 1996). In southern Illinois, Smith (1961) found adults to be common around the margins of cypress swamps bordered by rock bluffs (Petranka 1998).
